rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. Naiden is an absolutely amazing professor. His lectures consist of relevant course material connected with current events, wit and humor that make for both an entertaining and informative lecture. You honestly won't want to miss it, he is so well spoken and passionate about his field. The class is difficult, but well worth the work.

Professor is clearly a genius and very passionate about the subject.  However, Naiden is a very disorganized lecturer and you never know what he is important and what isn't. Tons of reading, at least 30 pgs of textbook per class. The 2 midterms and a final plus six essay assignments, which are hard because of his bad lecturing skills.

This class was SO hard! He rambles on about nothing to do with the readings or the slides on the power point- he doesn't even know how to work it properly. None of the hw content is discussed in class, it is so confusing and jambled. Tests are hard and the TAs grade the papers very harshly.  Struggled to pass this but got all  As in other classes.
He gives good lectures but is not the teacher to go to for office hours and even told me to drop the class when I became concerned about it

Professor Naiden is a scholar of high quality. If you want to learn ancient Greek history at Carolina, this is the person who knows more about than anyone else here. If you want to be babied DON'T take this class, but if you are driven and really want to learn the topic, this is the class for you. Would not recommend to non classics/history majors.

As said, Dr. Naiden is a top notch scholar with a seemingly photographic memory for Greek history. However, his lectures are the least organized and most confusing/ineffective I have ever experienced in 4 years of college. Expect to teach yourself everything, read book like the bible, and hope your TA can clarify the mush that will be your brain.

Naiden clearly knows his stuff. He is the eccentric genius type and it's evident that he's very passionate about what he's teaching. However, he has a tendency to plunge into a topic that is hard to follow. His powerpoints do not match what he's saying. If you read the book and pay attention in recitation, you should be fine.

He is a very geeky guy, but you can tell he loves what he's teaching. He's always willing to help if you have questions or need something clarified. He's very clear in what he will test on and what he's looking for.

Very strange mannerisms, and his lecture style was a bit... abrupt (?) and yet also kinda boring at the same time. Exams were your standard blue book essays, and some of the prompts for longer papers were a bit weird... Not a horrible class though.

Covers nothing of significance in class but requires attendance anyway. He is not very approachable, and was rude when I tried to speak with him.The midterms were not difficult in nature, but because he doesn't provide any study guide and they require a lot of detail they can be difficult to study for. The Final sucks.
Kind of strange character. Passionate but geeky.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. Talbert is extremely intelligent and has so much passion for his area of expertise.  His lectures are packed with information, so if you want to do well, definitely pay attention and come to class.  Being all new to Roman history, it was challenging to grasp the names and events.  But Talbert's accent and sense of humor helped get me through!

Professor Talbert is such an awesome professor! It's very clear to see his passion, and it seems as if he knows everything possible about the history of Rome. His expectations are very reasonable and the TA's were great as well. Sometimes the lectures were a little boring, but he randomly cracked jokes throughout which made it so much better.

Talbert is awesome. He is very entertaining in lecture, his British accent helps, and knows what he is talking about. He is clearly quite knowledgeable about Rome, and is quite enthusiastic. This class isn't terribly difficult, 5 short papers and 2 tests, but it is difficult to get an A. I highly recommend Talbert!

Talbert lectures in a narrative imbued with his signature dry humor. Lectures were very easy and enjoyable to follow. All in all, the class is very straightforward. You'll barely touch the textbook, but you do need to do the readings for each recitation and paper. Go to class, take notes, study, and you'll do fine.

I hate history but Talbert made Ancient History intriguing! My TA graded very harshly though and the readings for the 5 papers sucked. Otherwise you never have to read the textbook but to do well on the test you must attend every lecture and write down everything he says.

LOVED this class! He is so entertaining and there's never a dull moment! You can tell that he knows what he's talking about and loves what he does. The quizzes are actually trickier than the tests. You have 5 papers, and its easy to get at least a B on them. The TAs tend to grade a little harsh.
Richard Talbert is God. You must take his class with this in mind. Write down everything he has to say and watch the letters turn to shimmering gold script. Also study the textbook, he wrote it.
LOVED this class. History is not my forte and it was one of my favorite classes. Really engaging lecture. A lot of work, but totally worth it. TAKE. THIS. CLASS.

Very interesting lectures, has an awesome British accent/sense of humor. However, I made the mistake of going in to his office hours once, and let me say I have NEVER met a professor that gave off such an air of arrogance. Dismissive if not condescending to "lowly" undergraduates, but otherwise the course is quite nice.
Talbert is one of the best professors I've had at Carolina. I definitely recommend this class!

Prof. Talbert is a great professor with a good sense of humor and a very effective teaching style. His lectures are interesting and easy to understand. The class was a bit harder than I thought it would be. The TAs were tough graders and expected a lot of depth and analysis. Only had 50 min for exam essays and 2page papers.

Awesome prof! I honestly can't say enough how interesting he made his class, there was at least one good laugh a day. There are 6 short (2pg) papers graded by the TAs. 2 tests and a final, study past test. Attendance is kind of mandatory if you want the luxury of being bumped up a letter grade. Recitations almost killed me though, TAs are hardcore.

I've had Prof. Talbert for two classes now (226 and 106) and he is fantastic! Be sure to brush up on British idioms before you take his class, however (nerd= jerk, not geek) and prepare to take a lot of notes.  His exams are tricky but if you do the work, you should be fine.  All the grading is done by TAs, though, so be careful about that.

I loved this class!  I like history anyway, but even if you don't you'll fid him entertaining.  If you put forth the effort then you'll do well.  His lectures are very easy to listen to and comprehend.  Definitely take this class.  The readings on the syllabus help, but honestly I think his test/quiz material is very dominantly from his lectures.

He is a wonderful professor, and he definitely knows what he is talking about!  I would highly recommend taking a class with him!  Some reading is neccessary, but for the most part if you show up and take notes then you should know the material!
Great lecturer.  Every speech is made from memory.  TAs are pretty hard graders, but just keep good notes and you should be fine.

I never once cracked a book. Just study the notes, and ESPECIALLY his previous tests...all questions come from those! I loved the class, the papers weren't the greatest things because they weren't always related to test questions, but the class is well worth taking!

this guy is like watching a discovery channel special on the history of the Roman Empire.  He is an expert in his field and he makes his class very interesting, kept my attention throughout.  i touched the book once but you'll realize as long as you take notes it's obsolete to read his book. STUDY his past exams, he always pulls from them.
Charismatic, knowledgible, fun! Helps to like history!

Great professor!!! History of Rome with Talbert of my favorite classes at UNC by far. Entertaining British accent and one of the most intelligent and knowledgable people in the world on the subject, but doesn't teach the class at a too high level. Getting a good TA is key, also.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: He is a wonderful lecturer that is so fascinated by what he studied you can't help but be interested too. Stick to the readings as lecture progresses and his lectures make more sense. My favorite thing he says when class is finished is, "and that is the scene for today" and it really does feel kind of like story time, but way cooler. Great class.
Amazing lecture.  You must read all books, if you want to pass test. Also he is very serious about plagiarism. the work he checked by plagramme  plagiarism checker.

Dr. Whalen is a great professor. He really knows his stuff and is very excited to be teaching it. He structures the class so it does not burden you too much. However, the assignments do not have clear grading criteria. Overall, a great class though and I would definitely recommend.

Dr. Whalen is a very passionate professor who is always enthusiastic about teaching his class. Although his focus (at least for Medieval History) was mainly on the Church (an important part of Medieval History) and not much at all on castles and knights (what most people take Medieval History hoping to learn about), he keeps class upbeat and fun.
Professor Whalen did a great job.  He's energetic, articulate and always gives a thoughtful and well prepared lecture.  He gets the billing as the cutest professor in Christendom!

He takes attendance every single despite it being a lecture class but it is worth going to class everyday. He seems like he will be tough at first but he is super animated with lecture and uses all kinds of guides and tools to make the lectures super interesting. Definitely a class worth taking even if you don't like history.
Loved the class, the documentary he showed that he was in was awesome!

I took this class just to get rid of a Gen Ed, yet I was surprised at how much I enjoyed it, all because of Whalen. Medieval History is not an easy subject and the class requires that you take notes, study, and read A LOT, but Whalen is the most inspiring teacher I have had.  His passion and his genuine desire to see students succeed is incredible!

Brett really cares about Medieval History! His passion for his subject is the strongest of any professor I have encountered at UNC.  Attendance in recitation AND lecture is mandatory and taken daily. Everything is graded by TAs, so subjectivity often arises. It is a tough class but not impossible! It satisfies great general education requirements.

Dr. Whalen taught my undergraduate research seminar for my history degree and I would not have wanted anyone else. He's funny, engaging and super helpful. He genuinely wants to see his students succeed and gets so excited when you're doing well. Incredibly smart- he knows what he's talking about. One of Carolina's best. Take him if you can!

Professor Whalen is one of the best professors that I've had at UNC.  His passion for the medieval period is contagious (and I hated history going into the class).  He makes boring subject matter extremely funengaging, but you do have to work for your grade.  There is a lot of reading and lots of participation is expected.

I had Whalen for an honors course on medieval apocalyptic thought, his specialty. The readings were  dry but he makes up for it in lectures--he's engaging, funny, and brilliant. He grades fairly (not harshly)--your grade equates to how much effort you put in. He values student discussion and input. Overall, an amazing prof-take a class with him!

GREATEST. Professor Whalen is extremely excited about medieval history, and wants you to be as well. You must go to class and be typing notes nonstop, but his lectures are very interesting. Tests and papers are very straightforward, and a lot of your grade is participation. Hate history, but one of the top 3 classes I've had at Carolina!

Dr. Whalen is awesome!!! Funny, kind, fascinating lecturer, very helpful and accessible. Lots of reading, but reasonable amount of writing. Not an easy class, but definitely worth it. I hate history but I loved this class!

Great lecturer, but acts like you don't have any other classes to worry about. At least an hour of reading to do for every class period. Essays due way too often. Not to mention having an essay due on Friday and then a test the following Monday. Like I said, great lecturer, but way too much work for an intro level class.
Great professor, if you have the chance, take his class. Super helpful.
Absolute best professor. He's very concerned with his students understanding the material, he's a fascinating lecturer, and he's very clear about what he wants.

Prof. Whalen is one of the most interesting professors I have had at UNC. He is passionate about Medieval History and is fun to listen to. His lectures are always engaging, he is always cheerful and so excited about lecture you can't help but enjoy the class. The class is not the easiest but if you hit the books you should be fine.

Prof. Whalen is great, his class is always really interesting and fun to go to. If you have a chance to take his class, DO IT. As far as history classes go, this one is definitely one of the best Ive ever had.

Professor Whalen is an outstanding teacher, plain and simple. He has passion for the subject and presents information with perfect clarity. It's nearly impossible not to become enthralled and interested in his class.  Highly recommend.  I can't wait to take another of his classes!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Tough, judgmental, and just a bad professor for your first year. Will never take another class with Jay again.
My favorite professor, and I've never enjoyed a history class before. Very friendly guy, very down to earth. His teaching style is based more on discussion and analysis than on memorization.

An egomaniac.  He knows his stuff when it comes to France.  However, he has been in an out of class public debate against his own employer.  I do not agree with his opinion but I especially do not respect him bringing this into class.  He hates sports and athletes. He loves to put down anyone who may disagree with him.
Horrible professor.  Spent most of his time talking about how much he hates basketball and football players at UNC rather than tales of the GÃ©vaudan, which I was most interested in.

I had little interest in 516 before taking it but Professor Smith made it more interesting. Class was very laid back and assignments were all about thought and effort. Even though the course material was extremely complex, Smith tried to create a relaxed discussion environment. Interesting class overall.

I LOVED Professor Smith's class.  Lectures and documents were interesting and I always enjoyed recitation discussions. Although I think that depends on your TA. Do not take Hist 151 for an easy A.  I think there might have been 6 As this semester out of 150 or so. But I worked hard and got an A so it's not impossible.

Really nice guy. His lectures can be a little boring and he talks quietly so it can be hard to hear him, but overall the material is interesting. TAs have a lot of control over grade so easiness depends on them; assignments aren't too bad though, take-home midterm essays, a relatively easy final, and some easy MC quizzes.
I have never been able to stay awake though an entire one of his classes. He seems nice and respectful and sincere, but he reminds me of the ghost that teaches history in Harry Potter.

Lecture is pretty boring and he puts all the notes online, so you can get away with not attending. The midterms were fairly difficult and required a lot of memorization, but in class quizzes were easy. Didn't do much of anything for the class and still pulled out a B.

He's very easy to listen to and he really does make class time go pretty quickly. There are 5 quizes, but the one with the lowest grade is dropped. There are also 2 approx. 4pg papers, and 2 exams with short anwser and IDs. I got away w/o doing most of the textbook readings, but you do need to read the primary sources.
Class is pretty interesting for the most part. Lots of note taking. Easy quizzes. The tests aren't bad if you study lecture notes and do the readings. Class time goes by fairly quickly.
No Comments

Excellent Teacher, Really knows his stuff, and is very animated- so hes easy to listen to.  Quizzes are easy, but the midterms are fairly difficult- you really need to know the details.  Overall- probably my favorite class this sememster and I hate history.
he's very interested in his topics but he can get distracted easily..he's funny too :-)

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: There is a big discrepancy between professor and student. It was a small seminar-style setting, but I found my peers and I were afraid to make a comment or ask a question for fear of feeling stupid. She is constantly disagreeing with and challenging everything you say. This results in a confidence issue in class. I definitely learned a lot though.

Don't take a seminar class with her. She is very rude and condensing. If it's not what she thinks or feels then she talks down to you and embarrasses you. The language barrier makes things difficult. Only take the class if you are truly interested.

Insightful class with a professor who is an expert in her field. Extremely interesting with term paper as final. Lots of support from her with preparing the paper. I would like to take another class from her. Recommend.
Dr. Hagemann truly cares if her students succeed. Her criticism is constructive and she is a fair grader. I really enjoyed her class.

If you are interested in European History or Women's Studies, I suggest you take a class with Professor Hagemann. Yes, there is a fair amount of coursework and reading, but she is extremely knowledgable about the subject matter and the readings were very interesting.  She gives detailed instructions about what she expects from your assignments.
Not clear in what she wants, but then expects graduate level work. Extremely rude and condescending to students. DO NOT TAKE A SMALL SEMINAR WITH HER.

Professor Hagemann is an incredibly intelligent professor. I suggest taking one of her classes if you get the chance. Her style of teaching will help you reinterpret everything you thought you knew about history. Do not take one of her classes though if your not a serious student as they are difficult and writing intensive. Extremely helpful as well. She really means it when she says to go to office hours.

I would not recommend a small class with her. She was very rude to me on many occasions, esp when I emailed her about questions or concerns I had. I felt that she was targeting me specifically. If you answer a questions and its not what shes looking for, she shoots you down completely and embarrasses you. She expects way too much from her students!

Hagemann's lectures weren't always very interesting.  The bulk of what I learned in this class came from the reading.  Attendance was taken everyday.  I didn't think the language barrier was ever too bad; if anything, it's interesting to hear a different perspective on history.
No Comments

Though I have heard good things about Dr. Hagemann in lecture classes, do NOT take a small class or the history seminar required for history majors with her.  She expects way too much from undergraduate students (truly, she expects graduate-level work and time dedication) and is quite condescending and rude to her students.

Karen is a great instructer.  Her lecturers are not real helpful (could be a language barrier thing) but her assigned reading is really insightful and original.  In addition her background as a German professor is priceless in getting an alternative view of feminist history.  She is also really helpful if you need to meet her in office hours.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I loved having him as a professor. It was interesting to see his point of view of Germany's history. Would recommend taking him in the future!

I liked this class. Wish I could give higher feedback in all his categories, but the tests and papers are not an easy A. Prof. Jarausch himself is one of the best resources alive on the his topic. His voice is quiet in class, but if you listen, he lightens up the lecture with jokes and a funny perspective. I would definitely recommend this class.

He definitely knew what he was talking about, but his voice was kind of monotonous (with a slight accent and some jokes that would go over your head if you're not European) and the lectures were on the boring side.  He was writing a new textbook and gave it to us as a pdf so we didn't have to buy it.  Interesting class but not the best.

Dr. Jarausch is extremely humorous, and he's an adorable older gentleman. The class is easy - take notes during lecture, read the assigned novels (I'd say textbook is optional, and I read the textbook haha), and study the IDs before the exam and I'm sure you'll do fine. Loved Dr. Jarausch!

I enjoy his lectures, he has a great sense of humor.  But I feel the tests are geared towards the book... which I didn't read.  But overall, if you read the book and are prepared to study massive amounts of terms for only a couple to be put on the test, you'll be absolutely fine.

Very hard to pay attention in class.  Seems to want to wander off topic, just gives huge list of words @ semesters end and picks 5 random ones to put on the test.  Made me not enjoy history nearly as much as I used to.

Granted, he is very knowlegable, but his lectures ramble and it's hard to see the points he tries to make. I found it very hard to pay attention in lecture. The textbook is difficult reading (I thought) and some TAs are better than others. Some of them would give lectures when Jarausch wasn't in the country.

A lot of people like this professor. Personally, this was my least favorite class that I've ever had at UNC. If you already know some European Hist, you will prolly enjoy this professor. But, if you don't know hardly any Euro Hist prior to his class, good luck!

Sit close to the front because his thick German accent can be hard to decipher at times.  But he is a really great lecturer.  Powerpoints are easy to follow along.  He has a good sense of humor about Germany too.  And recitation sucks but if you go and contribute a few things to the discussion you're bound to get a decent grade.
I thought this class was amazing. Not only did Jarausch have a sense of humor, but his lectures were fascinating. I would take this class over again in a heartbeat.

I would take this class again. He invites a local Holocaust survivor to come in and speak for a day in class- its one of the most rewarding lectures I have ever had at UNC. Accent can be difficult, but hes very knowledgeable and really has well thought out classes. Tests are straightforward, but graded by hit-or-miss TAs.

Jarausch is great.  He is extremely knowledgeable which is apparent through his lectures.  I would suggest sitting in the front, as he is best understood (German accent) by those sitting close.  The topic is interesting, especially for someone like me who enjoys European history.  I would only complain about the recitations & you have to read a LOT

If you have any interest in European history, this is a great class to take.  He is very well respected within the academic community and that is obvious through his lectures.  The lectures aren't boring if you can get past the accent and if you have any interest at all.
No Comments

Top notch. Well known and respected in the historical academic community. If you're interested in Euro history, mark his course as a must. If not, I could see how his lectures could become a bit tedious.
Interesting and funny.  Not difficult to follow if you know a bit about European history.

Great professor, probably among the best (in terms of qualifications in their field) at UNC. His lectures can be somewhat hard to understand, due to his accent, but you'll definitely get something out of taking his class. Tets aren't bad, because you have a selection of questions to choose from.
Very boring lectures, hard to follow, the tests are long but fairly easy(must memorize a lot of terms, and there is an essay)
The lectures are pretty interesting, and the recitations and outside readings are well planned.  The tests are a bit tricky and require essays.
No Comments

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: You can tell that Professor Kramer definitely has a true passion for history and even though it's not necessarily my favorite subject, he made the material interesting. The class doesn't have much work other than short weekly readings, but you will have to study for the exams because they did cover tedious material.

1. Professor Kramer is precious 2. Take this class  There isn't really any work for this class on a day-to-day basis, but you definitely have to study for the tests. Professor Kramer is a super nice guy if you ever go to office hours, and I was never bored during his lectures. I definitely recommend taking a class from him if you can!
Interesting class, but not an easy A by any means.

Nothing's changed since 2005 (see below). Great guy and professor, but he has the TAs grade stuff absurdly hard. So if you're looking for an easy A, he's not your guy. But if you just want to learn and are ok with something in the B range then definitely take a class with him.

Kramer is very good! His lectures are funny and interesting. There's about 20 - 50 pages to read a week but it's not on the test so basically optional. He gives interesting antedates but normally you don't have to write them down so it's not hard to take notes. His few tests were not hard because you didn't have to answer everything.
Interesting class with about average work schedule.
Great class.  Great professor.
Kramer is the best professor at UNC!  He's brilliant and hilarious.

I really liked Kramer.  He's just a genuine, funny guy who obviously enjoys teaching.  He made the course very pleasant.  The lectures did get a bit redundant (partly because there was so much material to cover), but he did a good job keeping things interesting.  Kramer does a good job teaching but TA's grade harshly.  I still came out with a B+.

Dr. Kramer is definitely one of the best professors at UNC and made me consider becoming a history major. He keeps his lectures interesting and his passion for the course material is inspiring. He is really funny too and you should definitely take a history course with him.
Excellent Professor, he was extremely helpful and made the classes interesting.  All you need to watch out for are the TA's (they grade pretty hard)

Great, funny, engaging professor. One of the best at UNC- its professors like him who convinced me to major in history. For a huge survey class, the lectures are well done and tests are pretty straightforward (but graded by TAs). If you need, or even just want, a history class, you cannot go wrong with Kramer.

BEST history teacher I have ever had.  I have never really enjoyed history before but Kramer makes it enjoyable.  Lectures are enjoyable and class goes by quickly.  You won't regret having a class with him.

awesome teacher! if you, like me, are not too thrilled about history but have to take one for your perspective, this is the guy you want! made history lectures funny and interesting! tests are not too hard but the grading is a little strict. also, if you go to every lecture and take good notes, there is no point in buying the textbook.
good lectures, easy tests graded by crazy hard TAs
very good!
BORING BORING BORING
Hilarious and brilliant.  The best professor you will ever have in your miserable little life.
I agree with the reviewer above.  It's been almost 3 years since I had his class but I think he was the best teacher I had at UNC.

This guy is amazing. He is humorous and respectful. It is obvious that he cares about his students.  He makes history come alive.  Professor Kramer is probably the best professor in the entire history department at UNC-CH.  I recommend him highly.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. Reid isn't very clear when he asks questions on exams and many times his lectures are both boring and confusing. He's very smart and sort of funny but he talks very fast and gets off track easily.
Draws the A line at 95, be very cautious about taking a class from him.

Reid is a nice guy in person but his class is pretty tough.  The paper assignments are difficult and expectations are a bit unclear.  The grading on papers is also tough but the tests aren't too bad and he gives the questions before hand.  You also have to read cause half the exams come from the textbook.  Also I had a bad TA so that made it worse.

Professor Reid is very enthusiastic and helpful in person. His lectures are convoluted, but he cracks jokes and they seem to go by pretty quickly. The recitations are *amazing*. Essays are tough but the tests are simple enough, and he gives a generous curve. I would recommend for anyone who wants a better understanding of current events.

Professor Reid is quirky person and is passionate about history. He may not be the best public speaker but he really tries to get students interested. He ended up being my favorite professor this semester. The content the class covers is eye opening and interesting. The class wasn't too hard but it also wasn't easy.

Super boring lectures, then the tests are hardly based on anything he talked about. Memorize a whole bunch of pointless facts (not from the book).  Tough paper assignment in the beginning. Harsh on grading - 5 assessments make up a total of 100 points, so every point missed is a point off your final grade.

EXTREMELY boring lecturer. Has the longest and most convoluted essay prompts I've ever seen. Hard class not because the material is difficult but because he is a bad lecturer and his tests are difficult.

I had Professor Reid for a upper level research and writing seminar and I wouldn't have wanted anyone else. He worked with me to explore a topic that was somewhat unusual, but he encouraged me to pursue it. He is very articulate and I found him very helpful and supportive whenever I asked him about something. Great professor!

His lectures weren't clearly organized and he isn't the best speaker on campus.  Overall, the class isn't that difficult and uses fairly interesting books and films to teach.  If you interested in history or are looking for a class to fill, this isn't a bad option
His lectures are nearly impossible to follow.
choose another professor if u want coherent lectures. If not youll get his stream of conscious which is filled with tangents that dont relate to the topic at hand. He is not a good speaker
A wonderful, helpful professor.
I like the guy a lot, but found his class to be mediocre. Teaches off of books and movies, but still lost my interest.
Awesome professor. There's a good amount of work, but the class is a real learning experience.

Worst lecturer i've ever had. His lectures are disjointed and it feels like you're in a different class every time you go. Weekly quizzes require attendance, often had to read a book  or see a 3 hour film every week. Too much work required for this class for the level it is and none of it is enjoyable. Grading was harsh, multiple long papers.

His fuzzy head (and chest mind you) can distract you from his digressions. He finds it impossible to focus on one topic and follow it through in a logical coherent manner. Instead he meanders through vague themes "stepping back" every other sentence to re-clarify an already simple topic. prepared to do a ton of reading and sleeping in this class.
The class is kinda hard, and a B is to be expected.

Professor Reid definately knows what he's talking about. His lectures are a little jumpy and you have to read and write alot, but you learn so much. The sections are great because of the engaged TA's.
No Comments

Brillant professor, finally a challenge after breezing through high school. Many of my friends in the class thought it was vague or difficult, but that's just because they failed the quizzes on the assigned readings. You have to read things a couple of times to actually absorb the information, not just once the morning of.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: This class was dreadful. Each lecture felt like a stream of consciousness and she never got to the point. She was very disorganized and her teaching style was very ineffective. The amount of reading was ridiculous, for example: an entire book and four primary sources as a night of reading wouldn't be out of the norm. Avoid at all costs.

You can tell that she is very smart but her lectures are terrible. She is very hard to follow and I often walk away from class not being able to tell you one thing I learned.  There is an absurd amount of reading for an introductory course and the grading on papers/tests is harsh. I would not recommend this class to anybody!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: You have two options for this class: go to the lecture, or read the "textbook" (his own novel.) The grading is very specific -- do exactly what you think he wants, and do it to a t. You need to hit key points to make it in this class, and that means no rhetorical flourishes. Just tell him what he told you. The TAs did basically everything.

Chasteen is enthusiastic and knowledgeable about the subject. However, his lectures are very disorganized and he tends to ramble a lot. If you stop paying attention for 5 min, you are lost. Attendance in lecture is not required but it is for recitation. 1 midterm. 3 papers based on books. 1 final. Exams are ID style. TAs made the class v difficult

I'm a History major, but this class wasn't great. Chasteen's a nice man and I ended up with an A overall. However, the lectures have no structure whatsoever. He tends to ramble so often that his lectures are more tangential than actual substance. Still, though, it was a relatively easy course, if frustrating due to the lack of organization/clarity.

Professor Chasteen is a wonderful professor! One of the very best I've ever had at Carolina. He really knows his stuff, he's a great lecturer, you come out knowing the material backwards and forwards. I would recommend him to anyone.

Chasteen's lectures are boring and useless.  He rambles about something, and you learn the actual material from your recitation.  Taking notes in this class is pointless since the material is so easy.  I sat there most of the time asking myself why am i in this class.  But the worst part is that he takes attendance.

Weekly reads and responses, three papers that aren't bad - all graded by TA. IDK what the person below is on, but the lectures are important. He clearly lays out the themes of the course and connects ideas. Doesn't focus on the details.

I was very interested in the course material, but Chasteen's lectures are useless. If you do the reading, don't bother going. He just rambles about vague concepts. He says exams will not require specific knowledge of buzz words, dates, etc...but they are ID format. Beware. Not what I expected.

I cannot say enough wonderful things about Chasteen! His classes are always interesting and entertaining- I learned a ton. Take good notes and do the readings, and you'll do fine. One of the rare professors who knows how to keep you learning and interested without assigning ridiculous amounts of work! Take his class!!
Has students buy his books, including ones they may not need.

John Chasteen was an amazing professor. He keeps the material interesting. The reading isn't overwhelming and he does take attendance. Your TA will be a huge contributor to your grade. There were papers, which weren't too bad, and tests are essay.
Excellent professor.  A pleasure to learn from.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Great Professor! This class really opened my eyes!!!

This class is wonderful. Lectures were fascinating and always kept my attention, he teaches Cuban history as if he's storytelling. Yes, the class is painfully hard. Do all the reading, make notecards to remember names, go to office hours, think critically about the material. He can tell if you're making an effort, and that will make a difference.

Outstanding lecturer, but this class is extremely difficult. There are only two exams and no other grades (not even participation). The subject is very interesting, but don't take this class if you are only casually interested in history or latin america.

Without a doubt one of THE hardest classes I've taken at UNC. But absolutely one of the best. If you want a good grade you'll have to work your butt off and office hours are a must. You have to read and remember names. BUT I learned a ton; this class transformed my world view. If you are curious about Cuba, TAKE IT.
do not take

Dr. Perez is engaging and funny, and his lectures keep you interested while still explaining complex topics. History of Cuba is really difficult but I definitely recommend it, especially if you plan to apply to study in Havana while at UNC.

Dr. Perez is a very fair grader, but be prepared to copy notes furiously. Bring a tape recorder and highlight everything he writes on the board. Make sure you make note cards with every notable person in the reading, as these are all hot points on the tests. He is very enthusiastic about the subject and it is very easy to share that enthusiasm.

The class is interesting and it is obvious that Dr. Perez is very passionate about the subject and truly knows a lot about Cuban history. However the grading is harsh and working hard in this class does NOT necessarily mean you will do well!!! If you are concerned with your GPA I would NOT reccomend this class

This class was literally the most engaging class I've taken at UNC. He is an outstanding lecturer. I made a B in the class and worked hard, but I'm looking beyond that. He is the top scholar on Cuba, and man does it show in the classroom. Any serious student of Latin America cannot afford to miss his class.

Dr. Perez is incredible!  Truly one of the world's top Cuba scholars, and definitely #1 in the USA!  UNC is very fortunate to have him.  I agree that he is one of the most engaging, witty lecturers I've ever seen.  He grades fairly but demands a lot of his students.  Never be late!  Take his class before he retires!

wow! this is an entertaining class. it's a lot more like watching a play than listening to a history lecture. he is very animated. the readings are helpful, he is a fair grader, and is always available and happy to assist students during his office hours. yes, you have to work hard. yes, it pays off. you leave with a greater understanding of cuba.

Dr. Perez is amazing. His lectures are awesome and enlightening, despite the difficulty and complexity of the subject I feel like Perez did a great job covering Cuban history and Cuban-US relations. I would reccomend this class to anyone willing to put in the work. It is not an easy class but it is worthwhile.

The class was great; the person who wrote that Dr. Perez is a "propagandist for Castro" should have been listening in class, because that's far from the truth; of course it's pretty difficult to study Latin America without criticizing US foreign policy occasionally, which perhaps is what offended this guy.

I wanted to like this class so much, i did the readings, never missed class, had a solid background in the subject and it came down to him not liking my writing style, on our basically one exam that was our only grade. it was too bad too work so hard and get a c. it would be difficult to recommend though he is very passionate about the subject.

Absolutely brilliant! Perez is the foremost scholar on Cuban History in the nation and one of the most eloquent, insightful and witty lecturers the University has. His Cuba Hist class is brutally difficult (the only grades are a quiz worth 10% and two exams worth 45% each), but you will learn!
This dude has emotional issues with Cuba. He is a propagandist for the Castro dictatorship. Needs to get a life!

This was a wonderful class.  As long as you do the readings and attend class you will do just fine.  He really draws you in during class.  I definetely recommend this class and I am not even a history major.
Overrated and overpaid. Should get his head out of the clouds and retire.
No Comments

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: grading very tough

Professor Sevea is a wonderful human being and basically one of my favorite professors at Carolina. He is very helpful in and outside of class and has great lectures! This was an 8 a.m. class, but he made coming to class worth it!

Great professor. Very helpful. He would bring snacks and class involvement was good because he kept it laid back. The course was supposed to be on Southeast Asia but was pretty much entirely about India. Still, being Indian he really knows the material and is passionate about it. He gives great study guides prior to exams as well. Highyl recommend.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: This is a good class if you show up most of the time and take notes. You can download the power points and use them to study along with the study guides that she gives for the midterm and final, which are not too hard and graded very fairly. She wants you to do well and isvery flexible, even let me re-take the midterm so I could get a better grade.

Lectures are long and read from papers she holds during class, it's as if she's reading prose to the class. Not sure what it is about this method, but it makes the lectures dry despite being on interesting material. I've asked for help once from a TA and he was extremely responsive. An extra-credit paper was offered for this section, not everytime

This class was very dry, the lectures were boring, and the readings were long. That being said, Professor Radding really wants her students to succeed. Getting an A or B in this class is not out of the question if you are willing to go to office hours.
No Comments

Horrible professor--stay far away.  Has no idea how to teach undergraduates or how to use powerpoint in a lecture.  She tries to be friendly but actually has a very alpha-type, bulldog-ish, unapproachable personality that makes her defensive and even hostile.  I cannot imagine why UNC hired her.
Radding's class is sooooo boring!!!  I had her for a 3-hr seminar and the whole class was bored to tears.  Way to make a seminar full of bright students seem extremely dull.  DON'T TAKE HER CLASS!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Miguel is amazing! He's my favorite professor I've had at UNC and I'm totally going to take more classes with him in the future. Participation is so important and you can get points by responding to his tweets. The class is super straightforward and he's hilarious. If you show up and take notes, participate, and do the readings, an A is no problem
His lectures are always fun and engaging. I look forward to attending class.

Professor La Serna is my favorite professor that I have had at UNC. He is smart, funny, and incredibly helpful. If you ever feel like you are falling behind, just go see him in office hours because he genuinely cares about each student's success. The class was relatively easy. We had one midterm, a video project, and a final. Participation matters!

This is a very straightforward class. Material on the exams comes straight from his lectures and can always be found on the study guides he makes. Each exam consists of 7 short essay questions and 1 long essay. There are also two papers. These are graded by TA's and grades usually range from barely passing to mid-B's. And occasional extra credit!

Participation is key in this class! No final. 3 papers. A presentation. Participation. That's your grade. Write some solid papers and you are sure to earn a B. Participation grade may be the difference between a B or A. If you're more of an introvert like me follow him on twitter and respond to his tweets. If surprising helped bump my grade up!

He truly cares for his students. Grades consist of attendance, participation (debates/skits/discussion), a presentation, and three papers. There is no final exam for his FYS class. He is a fair grader. The most important thing is to do the readings. If you actually add some effort you can achieve an A. Without trying you can easily attain a B.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I liked this professor as a person, but as a teacher, she was disorganized. The syllabus was constantly not referred to and I felt as thought there was not much background included before we started discussing solutions. More organization would have helped this class a lot.

While the class isn't hard in terms of assignments (actually it's very easy), Professor Shields made the class absolutely unenjoyable. Her lectures are disjointed and the powerpoints only make things more confusing. She isn't a good teacher and I would NOT recommend her for this class. Maybe a class with a specific focus would be better with her.
The worst professor I have had a Carolina. Totally unreasonable in the amount of reading.

I was very disappointed in this class. The lectures were confusing & disjointed, the powerpoints useless, and the essays extremely frustrating bc of the former two. I took this class to get a general basis of knowledge in the Middle East, and that failed miserably. I only recommend this course if you are already well-versed in the region.

This is an amazing class with relatively few papers and midterms that will teach you a lot about the Middle East and give you a new perspective on history. There is a lot of outside reading, but you can get by without it. Weekly news and discussion postings are annoying, but otherwise, it's a fantastic class!

Professor Shields is extremely knowledgeable but kind of mean when it comes to simple questions. Her lectures are hard to follow because her powerpoints are difficult to understand. I love the class, I just wish it were more organized.

She's passionate about history and does a good job of involving even a large lecture hall, but she's somewhat scatterbrained. There is often little cohesiveness between lectures or even within a lecture, which can be very confusing.

This class had the potential of being great, but unfortunately Shields is impossible to follow. Her lectures are beyond unorganized and the power points are useless as well. The readings are long, tedious, and don't apply much to the topics discussed in class. I lost motivation for this class early on...

2 essays, postings and 1 page journal each week, map quiz, 3 events, and 5-6 page final paper. An extra credit paper (4-5 pgs) is allowed. It's possible to get a good grade, but the work is tedious.  Shields knows the subject, but is hard to follow sometimes. However, she gives a very balanced untainted view of history. The TA's grade everything.
Doesn't really know anything about effective teaching.
too many readings that were always too long as well. I'm an english major and I received a lower grade on her papers than on similiar ones for my english classes!

I had her for a seminar about palestine and israel. she gives you the documents, and then lets you decide. Then she will tell you about what happened. She is left wing, but she isnt biased. She can't change history.

Stridently anti-American and anti-Israel.  Do not take her if you want a balanced view of the recent history of the Middle East -- she is completely biased.  Extremely left wing professor.  Unfortunately, she's the only person who teaches Middle East history, so you're stuck with her.
Be warned -- she is a strong and vocal critic of Israel.  Her sympathies are completely pro-Palestinian, and she doesn't try to hide it.  If you support Israel, you will not enjoy her classes.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Aydin is a funny, interesting, and very intelligent man. His class seems hard at first but he is a very easy grader (I got 100 on every paper) because he cares more about you showing you learned something than actual grading. He assigns a lot of reading but you can get through it by skimming. There were no tests or quizzes.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Flatt was excellent. The FYS that I had with her was an amazing experience. The class was really easy with only a few assignments. The readings were difficult and often lengthy but not mandatory or necessary for understanding lecture. We did so many interesting things like movies,  museums and musical performances.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I took a 398 thesis class with Professor Tsin on the Chinese Cultural Revolution. The entire semester is spent writing an original thesis paper on the subject. It was daunting at first, but Tsin made the process incredibly enjoyable and rewarding. He had clear guidelines that helped along the way. I learned a lot and am happy I took the class!

Tsin was a great professor for History 133. The material was very interesting and I learned alot. The TA's grade your papers and he never sees them so be prepared to find a good TA. Enjoyable and pretty easy prof and teacher overall!

There are only 2 papers and 2 exams, if you didn't do well on one of them, there is no way for you to get an A. The materials are not very hard, but the grading completely depends on your TA. He does not even know what you write in a paper or exam.

Excellent teacher if you have any interest in the subject matter. Tends to go off on tangents but he is mostly enjoyable and a really friendly guy. Prepare to put some serious time into studying if you want an A though.

Sometimes hard to understand. Subject matter was pretty straightforward though, and much on pretty topical current events. Its a large class, with movies shown sometimes. Look out for weekly journal assignments.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Tasar was by far my favorite professor at UNC so far. He is very personable and even stopped the class to escort a student to CAPS because he wanted them to get help when they showed up to class crying. All of the readings are very interesting and he never assumes that he is correct. He is okay with being corrected and proven wrong.

I LOVE DR. TASAR!!! His class is everything a gen ed course should be-- interesting, useful, and not too much work. He is by far one of my favorite professors at UNC, and I am not a history person, so that's saying something. Everyone should try to take one of his classes while at UNC

At first I didnt take the class seriously and still did well. If you read the books you will get an A hands down. If you dont read the books be ready for a F. He is a great professor and I loved the books we were assigned to read. I would take this course again!

Didn't do so hot on a quiz so I went to his office hours to talk it over with him. He was so helpful and literally sat there and gave me points back as we spoke! He is very nice and responds well to students who are eager to learn. If you can, try to take a small seminar class with him rather than a large lecture class.
Attendance is mandatory and will have to do a lot of reading. He is very nice and understanding. I took the class during the summer and i thought it was an easy class.

He's great and lectures aren't boring. Only took class for geneds and I learned a lot from him. There is a lot of reading but he understands the college struggle. Also, for the final he was open for people to ask him questions and he responded almost immediately through emails despite it being really late at night
Professor Tasar was a decent lecturer and the quizzes were easy. The issue was the TA. There were four, but mine graded extremely harshly, so it wasn't that great an experience

Very enthusiastic about what could be a dry topic. I am not a history major and was only taking the class for GenEds but he made me want to take another HIST course at some point! As long as you put in at least moderate effort and take decent class notes you will be fine.
Very knowledgable, good at conveying all the information in an interesting and understandable way. Not many assignments. Lots of reading, but its not terrible and the books are not bad.

The class is VERY reading heavy. The lectures are bad, but a lot of the time there are little details that he doesn't always go over. However, he always does his best to answer any questions. He is always open to emails and office hours. Overall, he is very knowledgeable, sincere and fair. If you want to laugh in lecture take this class.
Professor Tasar is very knowledgable, friendly, and has easy quizzes. The class is reading heavy, and the TAs give most grades. Very interesting class though

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Raleigh is truly a great professor, easily one of the best in the History Department at UNC. His classes are enjoyable, his style highly engaging and his marking very fair. 477 is undoubtedly a challenging course which requires a lot, but if you put in the work you will find a professor always more than willing to support you.

Professor Raleigh is undoubtedly one of the most accomplished, experienced and interesting professors at UNC. If you have any interest in Russian history or history in general, this is a fantastic class. It isn't easy - theres lots of reading and you have to show up. But you know exactly whats expected of you and the grading is extremely fair.

What an absolutely incredible human being Professor Raleigh is. He tells the most engaging, insightful, and awesome stories I have ever heard. I have taken many, many history classes at UNC and, after his, there is no doubt in my mind that he is the BEST history professor at UNC. In fact, he is the best professor I have had at UNC. TAKE HIS CLASS

I went into the class just taking it for fun. I was called crazy by some, but I thoroughly enjoyed the class. This man KNOWS his stuff. I paid attention every class, took good notes, and I received the grade I deserved. If it weren't for one slip up, it would've been higher. He wants you to succeed and he respects you as a student. Top class prof!

Introduced me to a subject I knew very little about in an interesting way.  Don't take this course if you don't care about Russian History.  If you want to learn more-you'll enjoy Dr. Raleigh's classes

Raleigh is an expert in his field.  Unfortunately, his field is Russia, a country that is cold, boring, and uninteresting.  However, I did attain my personal best Tetris score while in attendance of his class. Advice: If you must take this class, take it with a friend who can counsel you when you inevitably contemplate your suicide (Thanks David!).

Professor Raleigh attempts to make Russia interesting; however, this is simply impossible. You will find yourself asking why you ever thought Russia's history could be interesting. Save your own life and sanity. One redeemable facet; the cute TA with a wicked foxyhot mustache (but I think he's studying in Russia now)Advice: Don't take this class!!!
When he says do the reading before class- DO IT!! or else you will fail

really knows his****. seems intimidating and cold but is really a great help if you ask nicely. but don't try to slack off or bs your essays because he will call you out on it, possibly in front of the class.

Fantastic professor.  He is an expert in his field, makes lectures engaging, and is just a very personable guy.  You definitely need to put some work into the essay tests but it's completely doable.  Take any class of his if you have any interest in history.
his classes are difficult, and he moves very fast, but he really knows his stuff.  do the reading in advance; then you wont be helplessly lost during lecture. tests are hard, but do-able.

reading and lectures are very important. he talks really fast though and will not slow down. however when it comes to papers, the grading is harsh. he and the TA's will tell you how to do it and then your grade will be low when u take their advice. sectionals are really easy...tests are NOT!
Do the reading, take notes, come to class and you'll do fine. Tests a little tough. I would recommended starting a head of time. On the essays, brainstorm first, outline second.
He is the cat's pajamas.

Very friendly professor, tough but fair.  His criticism is *always* constructive.  I never felt belittled in his classes as I did with other professors at UNC to be left unnamed.  He makes history come alive.  His area of expertise is in modern Russian history, a topic everyone should know a little about.  Take his classes if you can!
Really amazing professor.  Extremely well informed and passionate about his subject.  His classes are difficult, but with effort they are certainly do-able.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor DuVal is one of the nicest and smartest professors I've had.  She always encourages group discussion without making it awkward and seemed passionate about American history and her students.  She was great for the small seminar setting.

Professor DuVal was extremely enthusiastic about the material and made the lectures easy to follow. I actually looked forward to going to class every day, but that may just be me. As long as you keep up with the material and participate in the discussion in recitation every week, you should be fine. One of the best professors I've had at UNC.

I thought Professor DuVal was a good teacher until I got my final grade back. I was surprised to see that it was a B+ instead of an A-. 10% of my attendance grade had been deducted because I was in the hospital during one of my recitations. She sided with my TA when I asked for the points back on my attendance grade, saying that I shouldn't get the
Honestly, if you've taken us history before and do the reading for recitation, you don't need to go to class. All the work is based on the readings and some key terms that she posts online.

Her lectures are crystal clear and could not possibly be more straight forward. If you pay attention and care anything at all about history you should like this class. Professor DuVal is cheerful and loves her subject.

My experience with her might be slightly different than normal since she taught this class for the first time this year. There are a few kinks to work out with her method to teaching a film class but I think she is a great teacher. Her lectures are clear and insightful and she tells you everything that will be on the test beforehand. Study the IDs!

She is a great teacher with a good personality. There is reading every week and sometimes a paragraph, but the work is definetly managable. Recitation is interesting an enjoyable as well. The exams are fair, and follow the material taught in class, and with some studying the class is easy.
No Comments
boring lectures, pretty straight forward about tests though. you need to go to class though, my mistake.

Prof DuVal's lectures were interesting, it was a good class, not many assignments, very straight forward and clear. Had to do write a small paragraph on weekly readings, one quiz, a paper, a midterm, and a final. Highly recommended

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: He's really funny. Lectures are really interesting. The recitations involve competitions between teams, which is fun. However, there's a lot to read.

Outstanding professor, probably one of the best I've had in my college career. I am a former science major and have no passion for history classes. Dr. Lee motivated me to attend every one of his lectures, even though attendance was optional. I would recommend this class to anyone, even if you don't enjoy history.
Lee is a great lecturer. Zips through the material so be prepared to take plenty of notes but well worth taking this class.  Grading is up to the TA's so get to know them well.

Dr. Lee will fly through the material- make sure to go to class and take copious notes! The class is difficult not only because of the sheer amount of material, but also because your TA will be doing the majority of your grading. Try your best to figure out what criteria your individual TA is looking for (fancy vocabulary, etc) if you want a n A.

Dr. Lee will fly through the entire history of human warfare in one semester. It is amazing to watch and for the the many students who will only take one military history course he does a great job giving you a lifetime's worth of information. Highly recommended to everyone, PWAD major or not.

Great course. He is a very fun and entertaining lecturer. Be prepared to at least know the general ideas behind all the readings and take good notes. He also brings interesting weaponry to class, so its kind of show and tell!

Very interesting lecturer.  One of my favorite classes at UNC.  Due to the quizzes, it is recommended you attend class, but after listing to Dr. Lee, you won't want to miss.  The final is cumulative but if you do the work, you're fine.  However, there is A LOT of reading.  Overall, a fantastic class and I would definitely  recommend to anyone.

Professor Lee is great- very interesting and energetic. Attending lecture is important for quizzes. Final is cumulative but not too bad. Be prepared for A LOT of reading but his class was great and I would definitely recommend him to anyone!

Professor Lee is such a great teacher! He is knowledgable, energetic, funny, and respectful of student's opinions.  His knowledge of background information not found in the texts enriched the class and made everything very interesting. I'm usually pretty critical of my professors but Lee is definitely one worth taking a class with.
Loved the class- very interesting but be prepared for a lot of reading
Great professor. If you plan on taking a PWAD course, take it with Lee. But, be ready for a lot of reading.
No Comments
Wayne Lee is the man.  Take this class if you can.  Very very entertaining man.  Tests are not too bad.  Just pay attention in class and you'll be fine.

This is the best class I have ever taken.  The man is a genius and has an incredible amount of experience in the PWAD field.  Incredibly animated and entertaining, and tests are not too bad.  Take any class you can with this professor!!!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Great teacher! Knows history like the back of his hand. If you go to class the exams are easy!
Pretty terrible teacher in my opinion. He's kind of mean and he admits it, which is just absurd. I also had to deal with some really terrible TA that just made the class worse.
Very interesting teaching style.  No powerpoints, just straight from the hip and well knowledged.  Definitely will have to do all the readings as the exams will be based on them.

Lectures were very interesting, one of the best lecturers at UNC.  Tests are specific and difficult if your not prepared with the small details, but this is the case with many history classes.  Would recommend, but make sure you remember the terms he gives because your grade depends on it.

Professor Glatthaar's class is great. He teaches history from a fun facts and stories perspective so you don't have to be a history major to enjoy/do well in the class. Readings are interesting and reasonable, lectures are fascinating. He can be mildly offensive sometimes but I found it funny. Great class!
He is awesome! Very humorous and keeps class interesting.

Great Professor! He is absolutely one of the best professors at UNC and one of the best professors in the United States. One of the graduate students told me that he is known nationally. Even if you don't like history, take him! His average is a B, which at UNC means EXCELENTE!!! Also, he is very pleasant around students. Take Glatthaar!!!

Great professor. Going to class is a must & it really shows off if you do.  He's actually very friendly and will remember your face from class even if you don't speak. However, with 4 TAs doing all the grading, grading wasn't standardized. Also, Glatthaar sometimes shows his hotheadedness when things don't go his way. Overall an interesting class.

I liked Glatthaar.  Sometimes he was a little too opinionated...remember, it's history.  He was very knowledgeable about his subject and really seemed to enjoy teaching it to us.  Kind of liked how there was no textbooks, we just read 5 small novels.  However, he didn't allow laptops.  If you're good about takin notes & following a lecture take him

Great professor. He holds class the entire time, but his lectures are well worth it. A bit intimidating at first, but kind and helpful. No textbook, but the assigned novels are interesting and complement the material well. I highly recommend, even for anyone who doesn't like history. One of my favorite classes so far at Carolina.

LOVED Joe Glatthaar. I took him when he was at University of Houston.  He's a fascinating guy with tremendous life experience and wisdom!  Take him and you will learn to love history if you don't already!

He is wonderful! Very interested in the subject matter, and excited to be teaching it.  I thought history was ok, but he made it live! I would recommend him to anyone! No textbook, but novels to read that are interesting.  Also, he's funny and very lively.

I enjoyed his class so much in 128 that I wanted to take another history class of his (368)since I needed one. His lectures are never boring and he tells funny anecdotes that make class interesting. No textbook use, but lots of novels that you definitely should read. Tests are not terrible, about half fill-in and half essay. REALLY knows his stuff.
I have never enjoyed history until I took his class. He's a great teacher, and I learned a lot, but I only got a C+...

Funny guy who makes the huge US history survey course interesting. Sadly TAs will do all the grading and it can be really hit or miss. Then again thats the same for just about every big class like this one. Glatthaar is a pretty good teacher though, if you can deal with an occasionally irreverent style I'd recommend the class.

I really liked him as a teacher and would recommend his class but the grading is really dependent upon your TA. I found his lectures interesting and if you take notes, the tests are easy. The outside novels aren't that bad to read.

Amazinggggggg teacher. I adore the class. Tests are easy, just review the lecture notes (go to lecture) and my TA was extremely kind and fair in grading. He goes a bit fast in lecture but lets out early. Be prepared to read historical novels, but rarely any use of the history textbook! I recommend it.

Lectures rambled.  Grading was arbitrary.  Professor was rude to students, and he said anyone who disagreed with his opinions was an idiot (I kid you not).  He used a ton of foul language (and I mean he would make a sailor blush). People with positive reviews must be overlooking these faults.  Hard to make a good grade.

I found this teacher to be incredibly annoying.  Being a bit of a history buff myself, I found that he often got his facts/stories either mixed-up or entirely wrong.  With other reasons, this is why sometimes I couldn't stand going to class. It was like swallowing a cockroach for 75 minutes.  I realize my opinion isn't the popular one, but oh well.

Class was always interesting and he often told humorous history anecdotes.  Tests were only on information given in lectures, text book reading isn't required.  We had to read three books and write short essays on them during the tests.  The tests also included a long essay on specified topics in lectures and ten multiple choice questions.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Dr. Worthen gives amazing Lectures over interesting material.  Only History class I haven't fallen alseep in.  The class is worth taking, but does require quite a bit of work.

She was very particular with how things went. One of the smartest professors ive ever had, but also the hardest class ive ever had. Be ready to write long papers, and read a lot of material. This class is so thick with material and hard to keep up with unless you are very devoted to it. Hard class if you arent willing to put in the work.

Dr. Worthen is an incredible lecturer and very interesting to listen to. She really knows the material and you'll learn a ton in her class. That said, the lectures are very fast-paced and there are a lot of notes to take. There are pop quizzes and the tests and papers are hard. Great class, but be prepared to do work.

Professor Worthen is an exceptional (Yale-educated!) lecturer, but the class I would say has a very low work-payoff ration. In other words, you do a lot of work and get very little payoff (i.e. high grades) in return. Studying for the midterm and final was a nightmare. There is almost too much material to cover. You'll do a lot of reading, as well.

She is a very tough teacher and takes up every bit of her lecture. If you blink for more than you normally do, you miss a ton of information.I have about 120 pages of types notes for this class for the whole year. However, she is a great lecturer and very easy to listen to, it just gets a little long.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Simply the best

I had him when he was at Rutgers, back in the 1970s. A master of his field, he helped teach me the art of academic history. Do not miss the opportunity to take one of his classes. Don't remember the class code!

This guy knows his stuff. If you are interested in US war history I fully recommend the class. Lots of writing (5 essays) but interesting topics that compares to creative writing. TAs do the grading, mine was a good one. He schedules lots of movies for after-hours, some are fairly helpful, some aren't so much. Most can be rented.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Lisa is very very cool, and her class was really interesting. She put everything in a new perspective, and made me really interested in Global Studies. Her powerpoints don't make sense unless you go to class and hear her oral lecture, and discussion sections are mandatory. There are response writings, but they're not that bad. 9/10

Professor Lindsay is extremely enthusiastic about the subject, which makes it much easier to be engaged as well.  Teaching style is very chaotic though, which stressed me out sometimes, but it ended up not mattering as long as you paid attention because tests deal with broad themes, not really specifics.  Easy to get an A.  TAs are easy graders.

She's really into African history and knows what she's talking about. You don't have to read (except for discussion sections)... don't bother getting the textbook- just pay attention in class. I normally don't like history but she makes it easy to connect with

Dr. Lindsay is so smart and interesting. Her lectures could get kind of disorganized but she was always able to tie everything together. I'm not a fan of history but her class was engaging enough and is graded very fairly. Would recommend her to anyone!

Professor Lindsay is so intelligent but sometimes I felt like her lectures were kind of sporadic and not well organized. She eventually got her point across but she often rambled to get there. For that reason, you have to pay attention the entire time, or else you'll miss her point. She's super nice and easy-going though, so overall she was good!

Dr. Lindsay is a genuinely nice person, knowledgable, enthusiastic, and helpful. Most assignments in HIST278 required writing, but I personally enjoyed that. You still have to make effort to get an A, but I think it would definitely be possible to make an A without being extremely difficult. (you NEED to buy Atlantic Slave Trade by Northrup)
Great lecturer, very engaging, always offers help to students if needed.

I loved the class! I wish I had a chance to take more of Professor Lindsay's classes. She was obviously passionate about the course and it was a fairly easy course. It has been one of my favorite courses at UNC and I definitely learned a great deal. I highly recommend the course!
Dr. Lindsay is great.  Lectures are really interesting and is very passionate about the material.  Take her class
Excellent lecturer, although she gets into overdrive.  Voice takes a little getting used to.  She won't use the microphone so she gets a little screechy.
Very friendly and excited to teach the class. Interesting subject and lectures were actually a good use of time. The recitations, depending on the TA, can be the downside.

nice professor. probably easier than her ta's. she wants you to get the general ideas and themes. seems passionate about the subject, but can come across boring at times. workload is reasonable and reading is light. one of the texts is a book she wrote-easy reading. i recommend the class! good considering it's history.

I graduated and can honestly say that Professor Lindsay was the best professor I had at UNC, period!  She is so enthusiastic about teaching, so passionate about her material, so caring about her students!  She is dazzling in her lecture and her eyes really do sparkle!  I feel really fortunate to have had her.  I would love to repeat it!

Pleasing, smart, and pleasant, but at the end of the day, not that much soul or fire.  No way not to like her lectures, but unlike some of the students who have ratd her I found myself wondering whether this is just a job for her.  Sort of flat somehow.

Prof Lindsay is a fantastic lecturer--engaging, motivational, and clear--and she makes me want to know what she knows.  Excellent grasp of subject and ability to convey it.  It doesn't hurt that she is really pretty, either, but it seems there is consensus there.
Professor Lindsay is a joy to learn from! She's extremely enthusiastic about the topic and does a great job teaching it. The class itself is pretty easy. Definitely take it if you want an easy A!

Dr. Lindsay is the BEST professor I have had at UNC!  She is clear yet sophisticated, down-to-earth yet insightful.  She is witty with her words and yet brilliant in her interpretations.  She also knows how to make material accessible for students, and her passion for the material is quite inspiring.  What a gem!

Professor Lindsay is graceful and sweet, and smart as all hell.  Just when you start to think she's so charming, she dazzles you with this brainiac display.  And just when you're thinking she's a brain, she does something adorable.  I love this class.
No Comments

She really cares about her students. She recognizes that everyone in the class brings something unique to the class and that all opinions are worth hearing. Her enthusiasm for the subject is contagious, and even though I wasn't too excited about taking the class at first, it wound up being one of my favorites at Carolina!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I really enjoyed this class. The material is relatively interesting and he wasn't a tough grader. Maybe not an easy A class, but with some effort you should be fine. Reading isn't mandatory and he doesn't take attendance, but showing up to class is important to understand the material.

Professor Watson is very knowledgeable and his lectures were actually interestinginsightful, but reading the textbook is an absolute MUST for success. He doesn't really teach the plain and simple facts that you must know for the midterms - he just assumes you know it, and dives into deeper ideasside stories.

Professor Watson is incredible! He knows more than almost anyone else will ever know about the antebellum American South. He is friendly, brings a smile and a good attitude to class and is always well prepared and clear in his lectures. I am a history major and he is the best history professor I have had at Carolina.

Very interested in material, but not the best speaker. Could be soporific if you don't bring a caffiene infusion. Do the reading and take good notes! Talk to your TA about the essays and preview the exams. You should do fine.

I hate History, but his class was still one of the best I have had thus far.  His lectures are interesting, and he constantly repeats topics that are prominent on the exams.  Pay attention and contribute in reciation because it effects your participation grade and the TA's impression of you.  He/she will be grading your work.

Really loves the course material.  Very excitable on class.  Lots of reading but not too bad.  Doesn't give study guides so you've got to have a broad understanding of the course material come exam time.  Discussion sections provide insight and clarifying.    Cares about his students.

Professor Watson is very nice.  The course readings can be VERY long and sometimes repetitive, but they are original documents and not simple tellings of the history (you have to go to lecture to get that).  The recitations require critical thinking.  This was a very enjoyable class; I recommend it.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: She's the best Professor I have had at UNC. I love her class and have taken two already. She honestly cares about her students and work. As long as you at do the readings (which are usually pretty interesting) and participate in class every once and a while you will be fine. Take a class with her- you won't regret it.
Love her! Super helpful and very willing to accommodate if you show an interest in the work

This class was really enjoyable. It's a lot of powerpoint and lecture, but the subject matter was interesting and the recitation sections were usually really nice too. THe papers are tough, especially if you've never written historical analysis, but I also think my TA was a tough grader.

Here lectures cover a lot of material. Take good notes as her few slides per PPT are mostly pictures. Recitations are a must. TA has almost complete autonomy over your grades. Two papers, a midterm, and a final. I was one of about five guys during Fall 2015 session. Not sure that had any impact on grades. Wasn't a feminist going in & still not.

Prof Turk is nice and willing to help. However, your TA decides your grade.  Your grade is composed of 2 essay midterms and 2 papers, all of which are graded EXTREMELY subjectively. Grades were never posted until the night before the final and little feedback was ever given. She also doesn't round for grades. I would not recommend taking this class

I took her Women Studies Class and she's a good prof. with pretty straight forward tests and very little homework however if you're worried about your grade it's almost entirely up to your TA  for the class.
